Notably it's trying to create a sync signature for a pretty old slot - the one that was current right as the node started up.  But there are no active validators (one not yet deposited and one in the pending queue) so there shouldn't have been any scheduled duties.

FWIW, further context on this.

The specific use case I was testing on `teku-testnet` server (logs above) was that of running 2 Validator keys, where 1 is active and 1 is inactive. This is to verify whether it is safe to:

1. Configure the software to recognise `n+m` validators (`n` and `m` positive integers), where `n` validators are active and have deposited, and `m` are inactive and are yet to be deposited.
2. Run with `n` active (and `m` inactive) for some time
3. Deposit to for the `m` inactive validators, and test their successful activation
See attached `teku.log` file for full stack trace: [teku.log](https://github.com/ConsenSys/teku/files/7176677/teku.log)

I was actually able to reproduce this, admittedly with active validators, but the theory is the same.
Basically if there are none of your validators in the current sync committee, you will get this IllegalStateException appearing. 
On the plus side, while it's unsightly, it's not causing actual data problems or network traffic, but we really shouldn't be showing this error, because basically there's nothing to do and we try to perform tasks without any validators to work with.
I really appreciate the retest, i wasn't able to replicate it yesterday, but thankfully we got another way to get into that scenario today, so i was able to see the problem and prove it has been resolved with the code build from #4380
